Remove docker images older than one month:

1047237812783894528.text: TIL: The bash help command's argument is a regex, not an exact command. Thus you can give it partial matches and patterns.So 'help co' shows the help for any bash internal command starting with 'co' and 'help "*t"' shows the help for internal commands ending with a 't'.

991101925042081797.text: [Ctrl-d] # Last one for today. This indicates to the program that there is no more input. In the shell, this usually closes the shell.

991093618709618690.text: [Ctrl-u] # Delete everything from the cursor to the beginning of the line. This can also be used to clear a password attempt and start over.

991085816016404480.text: [Ctrl-w] # Delete the previous word on the command line (before the cursor). This is highly useful when reusing old commands.

991079523188961281.text: [Ctrl-l] # This is usually equivalent to running 'clear'.  Its usually quicker and doesn't leave the command in your command line history.

991071972116361217.text: [Ctrl-_] # Incremental undo of command line edits.

991064169129611264.text: [Meta-#] # Comment out the current command from the beginning of the line. Faster than [Ctrl-a] then #.

991057372612263938.text: zless, zgrep, zcat, zdiff # There are helper commands for dealing with compressed files (gz, bz2 and xz). They have a z, bz or xz prefix.

991050073105731584.text: [Meta-.] # Insert the last argument from the previous line in the command history into the current line. This is different from using !$ Press multiple times to keep going back through each history line's last argument.

991049534376726531.text: Those asking "Why not use Home and End?" These aren't setup in every distribution or are setup incorrectly. Some keyboards also lack them.

991042989974786053.text: [Ctrl-e] # Move your cursor to the end of the line. Faster than holding down right arrow.

991034683847831552.text: [Ctrl-a] # Move your cursor to the beginning of the line. Faster than holding down left arrow. In screen, you need to press <Ctrl-a a>

991027887397572608.text: [Ctrl-r]string # Reverse search through your command history for 'string'. Press Ctrl-r again to continue searching backwards. ESC when done

991021594507128832.text: The next several tips are readline shortcuts you can use in Bash by default and other shells. See Readline Command Names in bash man page.

991014798371573760.text: ascii || man ascii # The || logical OR operator will run the second command only if the first command fails. For instance, this will only run 'man ascii' if you the ascii command fails or is not found.

991006240573706240.text: tmux # tmux is a great program that manages multiple terminal sessions and allows you to detach/reattach to the session. Also screen, dvtm.

990999695966302208.text: ps auxww | tee output.log # Use the 'tee' command to save a copy and see the output of a program at the same time.

990992144860172288.text: man -k sound # Use -k to search for something in all man pages, like 'sound'.

990985600152100864.text: help cd # There are several commands inside bash called 'built-ins'. You can access info about them using 'help builtin' or just run 'help'

990978048576147458.text: ls -ltrah # Print detailed list (-l) of all (-a) files reverse sorted (-r) by last modified time (-t) and with human readable size (-h)

990971000631283718.text: pushd and popd are also common programs you can use for moving around the filesystem. See 'help pushd' and 'help popd' for info.

990963701208535040.text: cd - # Takes you back to the previous directory you were in. Good to know if you don't already.

990960225892159489.text: cd # (With no arguments, not even the #) Takes you back to your home directory from wherever you are.

990959335512641536.text: Also, @climagic tips are based on the BASH shell version 4+ with Emacs readline mode on GNU/Linux. I do this because it's the most common configuration for most people these days. No problem with using other shells, modes, desktops, OSes or editors. Use what works for you.
